body: I have SteamWorks access, so I'll set up a proper test for this.
Verified with minimal Steam API example.
Shouldn't need to use the Steam API for just the overlay, btw. You can start any app through Steam to force the overlay to show up, or likely simply preload the overlay lib for any app.

Thanks, good to know.

Using raw input isn't a good fix for this, not because raw input isn't a Good Thing, but because it should be implemented simultaneously on all platforms (#125) and should only be used when the cursor is disabled (because the data by definition won't line up to the processed, visible cursor position).

My suggestion for a quick fix is that you leave XInput2 detection forcibly disabled and rely on core events.

If I can't find a sane way to detect when it's a good idea to leave XInput2 alone, I'll add a compile-time option for playing well with SteamWorks.

Also, ping, is this an acceptable solution?

Absolutely. The fewer compile-time options the better.

The transformed values of raw motion events are in screen coordinates, not local window ones, which is somewhat more problematic on X11 than other platforms, but I will look into it.
Any update for this issue? I have the same problem.
@Wotan Not yet. Until then, my recommendation is to forcibly disable XInput2 detection. This will let GLFW play well with the Steam overlay.

issue.body:
The steam overlay on linux doesn't receive mouse motion and mouse button events. 

It appears the folks at glfw had the [same problem](https://github.com/glfw/glfw/issues/304) and it's due to XInput2 event masking.

Commenting out a few [lines](https://github.com/rust-windowing/winit/blob/master/src/platform/linux/x11/window.rs#L344) from the mask seems to fix it, but I'm not sure what else will that break and where. Even when they are missing from the event mask the window continues to receive mouse motion and button events and they appear in the output.

[Short clip demonstrating the problem](https://youtu.be/YS7FlLCcBCM)

EDIT:
No, commenting out those lines actually breaks mouse input.
